text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's German newspapers:
- Critics of Labour Minister Norbert Bluem say his pension reform plan not enough to meet goal set by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of cutting level employee pension contributions.

- Kohl breaks ground for start of new chancellery in Berlin, says construction project cements government's move to Berlin in the year 1999. Avoids questions about whether he will run for reelection in 1998.

- German machinery making industry expects to cut more jobs in 1997 despite production gains of three percent. VDMA expects 10,000 of 945,000 jobs to be eliminated this year. About 40,000 jobs were cut last year.
- Madcow disease hurting profit developments for German farmers, says Agriculture Minister Jochen Borchert.
- BDI president Hans-Olaf Henkel supports Finance Minister Theo Waigel's tax reform plans.
- Economy in west Germany grows only moderately in January and February, according to early indicator index.
- Numerous printers go out on token strike.
- Newspaper printers walk off jobs in token strike over labour dispute. About 7,500 workers nationwide in 120 printing plants walk off job just before sixth round of wage talks start.
- Bonn wants more information from Iran about author Sarkuhi.
- Train with nuclear waste in France near German derails.
- Agriculture Minister Jochen Borchert says German farmers could lose 700 million marks in year 1995/96 because of BSE scandal.
- SPD sends cooperation signals to government in dispute over tax reform.
